row.entry: This Division contains provisions relating to the delivery of reasons for judgment, consent orders and, the content of formal judgments. Other provisions determine the date on which judgments take effect and the time for compliance with judgments.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Entry of Judgments and Orders — Rule 36.11

row.entry: This rule defines the manner in which judgments are entered.
These rules regulate the service of judgments and orders.

entry.emph: Division 4 — Setting Aside and Variation of Judgments — Rules 36.15–36.18

row.entry: These rules set out circumstances in which judgments and orders can be corrected, varied or set aside, otherwise than by appeal.
This Part applies to all courts in CPA Sch 1 except r 36.8 which does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The rules in this Part are principally based on the former SCR Pts 40 and 41, DCR Pt 31 and LCR Pts 11 and 26. The present rules are substantially the same as their predecessor provisions. Rules 36.15 and 36.16 combine slightly differently worded provisions from the previous rules and make explicit the courts powers to set aside any judgments obtained irregularly or in breach of good faith.
Absence of a party — orders made in ‥ [36.16.5]
Absence of party — setting aside judgment entered in ‥ [r 36.16(2)]
Appeal — relevance of reasons to rights of ‥ [36.2.35]
Consent to set aside and consent judgments ‥ [36.15.5]
Costs arguments after judgment has been formally entered ‥ [36.16.12]
Date of effect of judgments and orders ‥ [r 36.4]
Date when the judgment takes effect ‥ [36.4.5]
Default judgment — Delay in bringing application to set aside or vary ‥ [36.16.30]
Delay — adequacy of reasons where judgment given after substantial ‥ [36.2.25]
Desirability of trial judges determining all issues ‥ [36.2.40]
Discretion to order judgment takes effect from earlier date ‥ [36.4.7]
Entry of judgment — setting aside after ‥ [r 36.16(2)]–[r 36.16(4)]
Entry of judgment — setting aside before ‥ [r 36.16(1)]
Example of the application of the slip rule ‥ [36.17.10]
Exclusions relating to the Local Court Small Claims Division ‥ [r 36.8], [r 36.15], [36.16]
Failure to give reasons and error of law ‥ [36.2.30]
Fraud — impugning foreign judgment obtained by fraud ‥ [36.15.25]
Fraud — setting aside judgment obtained by fraud ‥ [36.15.20]
Interlocutory orders made by consent — variation of ‥ [36.16.40]
Irregular judgment — incidental irregularity and sufficient cause ‥ [36.15.15]
Irregular or illegal judgment — substantial irregularity ‥ [36.15.10]
Judgments and orders — variation of non-determinative aspects ‥ [36.16.52]
Judgment entered — specific, limited power to alter ‥ [36.16.53]
Judicial notice to be taken of orders and undertakings ‥ [r 36.6]
Liberty to apply — further consideration reserved ‥ [36.16.70]
Order for payment of costs to be assessed ‥ [36.4.10]
Order for payment of costs where the amount is fixed or agreed ‥ [36.4.15]
Procedure for entry of judgments and orders ‥ [36.11.10]
Setting aside and variation of judgments ‥ [rr 36.15–36.18]
Setting aside summary judgment registered locally when foreign judgment is set aside ‥ [36.16.17]
Variation of judgment or order against party operating under unregistered business name ‥ [r 36.18]
Winding up orders made in the absence of a party ‥ [36.16.85]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.1] r 36.1 General relief (cf SCR Part 40, rule 1; DCR Part 31, rule 8; LCR Part 26, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: General relief (cf SCR Part 40, rule 1; DCR Part 31, rule 8; LCR Part 26, rule 1)

p.text: At any stage of proceedings, the court may give such judgment, or make such order, as the nature of the case requires, whether or not a claim for relief extending to that judgment or order is included in any originating process or notice of motion.
Legislation cited in [36.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 90.

CPA s 56 requires courts to give effect to the overriding purpose of facilitating the “just, quick and achieve resolution of the real issues” in proceedings. That obligation is complemented by both CPA s 90 and the present rule. Both require courts to give “such Judgment or make such order as the nature of the case requires”. A similar obligation (in Supreme Court Act 1970 s 63) has been interpreted as requiring the determination of all matters in dispute between the parties, including any entitlement of the defendant irrespective of whether or not any formal cross-claim has been filed: Dunne v Elibank-Murray (1982) NSW Conv R 55–057 (NSW Court of Appeal). Consistent with that view, in proceedings for a declaration, it commonly happens that a court may when, resolving proceedings in favour of a defendant, make a declaration contrary to that sought by the unsuccessful plaintiff, even though no formal claim was made by the defendant: Harrison-Broadley v Smith [1964] 1 All ER 867; [1964] 1 WLR 456 ; Loudon v Ryder (No 2) [1953] Ch 423 ; Graham H Roberts Pty Ltd v Maurbeth Investments Pty Ltd [1974] 1 NSWLR 93 ; Farrell v Mulroney [1978] 1 NSWLR 221 . Such a declaration will not be made if there are contrary matters that were not raised by the parties in the proceedings: Re Maiorana and the Conveyancing Act (1970) 90 WN (NSW) 365 at 376–7.
The court may give judgment, or order that judgment be entered, in the terms of an agreement between parties in relation to proceedings between them.

Unless the court, for special reasons, otherwise orders, the court must refuse to give judgment, or order that judgment be entered, in terms that restrict, or purport to restrict, any disclosure of the terms of the judgment or order.

Subrule (2) does not limit the effect of any agreement between the parties that contains provisions that restrict the parties, or purport to restrict the parties, from disclosing the terms of the agreement or of the judgment or order.
[r 36.1A insrt Amendment 13 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[9], effective 5 April 2007]

The approved from for a consent order or judgment is Form 44 . To reduce the number of settlement consent documents rejected by the court, (resulting in delay, further cost and sometimes unnecessary court appearances) the District Court has prepared and published a checklist to clarify the process of applying for a consent judgment. See http://www.districtcourt.justice.nsw.gov.au/districtcourt/case_types/civil_cases/settlements.html .
Legislation cited in [36.1A.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 Ch 3.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 588FF.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 36.1A(1).

Ordinarily a court ought to make any consent orders requested by competent and interested parties to the proceedings if the orders are within the court’s jurisdiction and otherwise appropriate: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Real Estate Institute of Western Australia Inc (1999) 161 ALR 79; (1999) ATPR ¶41-673; [1999] FCA 18; BC9900036 ; Noel v Becker [1971] 2 All ER 1186; [1971] 1 WLR 355 . The qualifications of jurisdiction and propriety contained within this general proposition suggest a range of circumstances that illustrate the propriety of a refusal to make the order requested: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Albert (2005) 223 ALR 467; [2005] FCA 1311; BC200507021 . These include the following examples:

where the order involves variation of, or departure from, the ordinary procedure of the court: Cherwell District Council v Thames Water Board [1975] 1 All ER 763; [1975] 1 WLR 448 at 450 ; Sydney City Council v Ke-Su Investments Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 246 ;

where the orders requested do not accord with legal principle or are couched in vague and uncertain terms: Thomson Australian Holdings Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1981) 148 CLR 150 at 164; 37 ALR 66; BC8100114 ; Dietz v Lennig Chemicals Ltd [1969] 1 AC 170; [1967] 2 All ER 282 ; Kovalev v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (1999) 100 FCR 323; 59 ALD 71 (order setting aside administrative decision);

where there is either no jurisdiction to make the order or doubt as to the court's jurisdiction: Forsyth v Forsyth [1947] 2 All ER 623 and Thomson Australian Holdings Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission, above,at 163 ; Xiao v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) 109 FCR 129; 65 ALD 479; [2001] FCA 459; BC200101872 ;

where error is a precondition to the favourable exercise of appellate power, but has not been demonstrated to affect the original decision: Allesch v Maunz (2000) 203 CLR 172; 173 ALR 648; [2000] HCA 40; BC200004312 at [23] ; Telstra Corporation Ltd v Minister for Broadband, Communications and the Digital Economy (2008) 166 FCR 64; 246 ALR 15; [2008] FCAFC 7; BC200800551 at [51] . (However, it is likely that UCPR r 36.1A(1) and SCA s 75A(10) would be construed to permit any ordinary consensual disposition of an appeal to the Court of Appeal: see also Citigroup Pty Ltd v Mason (2008) 171 FCR 96; 250 ALR 7; [2008] FCAFC 151; BC200807479 .);

where a material change of circumstances has occurred since the parties agreed to the judgment terms: Groser v Equity Trustees Ltd (2008) 19 VR 598; [2008] VSC 163; BC200803436 at [39] (Family Provision applicant died between settlement and the application of consent orders — orders refused).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.2] r 36.2 Written reasons for judgment (cf SCR Part 40, rule 2; DCR Part 31, rule 9; LCR Part 26, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Written reasons for judgment (cf SCR Part 40, rule 2; DCR Part 31, rule 9; LCR Part 26, rule 2)

p.text: If the court gives any judgment, or makes any order or decision, and its reasons for the judgment, order or decision are reduced to writing, it is sufficient for the court to state its judgment, order or decision orally, without stating the reasons.

After a judgment, order or decision has been stated orally under subrule (1), a written copy of it, including the court’s reasons for it, must then be delivered to an associate, registrar or some other officer of the court for delivery to the parties or may instead be delivered directly to the parties.
Legislation cited in [36.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.2(2).

Delivery of written reasons is the usual judicial practice. The present rule specifically authorises the publication of written reasons and makes clear there is no requirement that they be read aloud. In this respect, the rule restates the general position that applies to superior courts of record. There is an inherent power for a superior court to make orders, and give reasons later: Au Pui-Kuen v Attorney-General (Hong Kong) [1980] AC 351 at 356 per Lord Diplock; Fletcher Construction Australia Ltd v Lines Macfarlane & Marshall Pty Ltd (2001) 4 VR 28 at 43; [2001] VSCA 167; BC200106100 ; King Investment Solutions Pty Ltd v Hussain [2005] NSWSC 1076; BC200509160 ; and practical necessity may sometimes require the adoption of that practice: Stratford v Ministry of Transport [1992] 1 NZLR 486 at 488–9 (decisions on applications for interim relief or rulings during a jury trial).

The position in relation to inferior courts is determined by the provisions of the relevant legislation and may require a particular method for the publication of written opinions. The validity of the court’s judgment may depend upon strict compliance with those provisions: Ex parte Currie; Re Dempsey [1970] 1 NSWR 617; (1969) 70 SR (NSW) 443 . In the interpretation of r 36.2(2) , the word “then” means “at that time”, not “at any time thereafter”: Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 at 173 . Consequently, apart from compliance with the present rule, judicial officers in inferior courts ought not adopt informal means of making orders and notifying them to the parties: Robert William Cumming v Tradebanc International Ltd [2002] NSWSC 70; BC200200386 at [38]–[58] .

General requirement for reasons: Explicitly reasoned decision making, typically in the form of written reasons for judgment, is fundamental to the proper administration of justice and the integrity of the judicial process: Soulemezis v Dudley (Holdings) Pty Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 247 at 279 ; M D Kirby, “Reasons for Judgment: Always Permissible, Usually Desirable and Often Obligatory” (1994) 12 Aust Bar Rev 121. Public Service Board (NSW) v Osmond (1986) 159 CLR 656 at 667; 63 ALR 559 at 566; BC8601404 per Gibbs CJ; Housing Commission (NSW) v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378 at 385–6; (1983) 53 LGRA 325 per Mahoney JA: Re Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Ex parte Palme (2003) 216 CLR 212; 201 ALR 327; [2003] HCA 56; BC200305703 at [105] per Kirby J (rationale of the obligation to give reasons in administrative matters but capable of wider application). Consequently reasons for decision are a necessary incident of judicial decision making in general, without their expression being universally required for every particular judicial decision: R v Awatere [1982] 1 NZLR 644 at 649; Public Service Board (NSW) v Osmond , above; Brittingham v Williams [1932] VLR 237 at 239; [1932] ALR 176 ; see further [36.2.20] (dealing with procedural decisions).

Extent of obligation to give reasons: The extent of the duty to give reasons depends on the nature of the particular decision, the circumstances in which it is made and the purpose that the statement of reasons is intended to serve: Mifsud v Campbell (1990) 21 NSWLR 725 at 728; Beale v GIO (NSW) (1997) 48 NSWLR 430 at 443–4 per Meagher JA. As a result, the scope of the duty is not capable of precise definition: Housing Commission of New South Wales v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378 at 381, 385–6; affirmed Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd v Housing Commission of New South Wales (1984) 54 ALR 155; 58 ALJR 553 . At one extreme, some authorities suggest that, in particular circumstances, the mere statement of the court’s conclusion may sufficiently indicate the basis of the judgment: Sun Alliance Ltd v Massoud [1989] VR 8 at 19; BC8800706 . (Particularly is this so where the relevant matter is too plain for argument: Mohamad Kunjo S/O Ramalan v Public Prosecutor [1979] AC 135 at 142 ; or, perhaps, where the decision depends entirely on credibility: Qushair v Raffoul [2009] NSWCA 329; BC200911105 at [53] and [54]). At the other extreme, detailed reasons are particularly required where the ultimate judgment is the result of a complex process of reasoning and evaluation: Donovan v Edwards [1922] VLR 87; (1922) 28 ALR 51 ; Gamser v Nominal Defendant (1977) 136 CLR 145 at 149; 13 ALR 387; BC7700032 ; R v Local Government Board; Ex parte Arlidge [1914] 1 KB 160 at 187 ; or where they are necessary to give content to a right of appeal: see further [36.2.35] .

Content of reasons: Between these extremes, even though the circumstances will generally require written reasons, it is not always necessary to give elaborate reasons: Ex parte Powter (1945) 46 SR (NSW) 1 at 5 . In particular, it is not necessary to make express findings in respect of every matter of fact or law that has been raised in the proceedings: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Yusuf (2001) 206 CLR 323; 180 ALR 1; [2001] HCA 30; BC200102757 ; Selvanayagam v University of the West Indies [1983] 1 All ER 824; [1983] 1 WLR 585 at 587 ; Housing Commission of New South Wales v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd , above, at 385–6; Soulemezis v Dudley (Holdings) Pty Ltd , above. Nor is it necessary for the written reasons to expose all of the detailed reasoning involved in arriving at the final judgment or decision: Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd (in liq) v Darling Harbour Authority (Paddy Markets case) (1991) 24 NSWLR 156 at 189; 73 LGRA 47 . Indeed, there are significant warnings against judgments being unduly prolix and over elaborate: Customs and Excise Cmrs v A [2003] 2 All ER 736; [2003] 2 WLR 210 at [80]–[84] . But subject to these qualifications, the general requirement is that a court should produce adequate reasons for decision.

Basic elements of properly reasoned decisions: As a general proposition, adequate reasons for judgment ought to satisfy three criteria. They should (i) identify the relevant evidence, (ii) record material factual findings and (iii) provide reasons for making the material findings in relation to the critical disputed issues of fact and law: Pollard v RRR Corp Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 110; BC200903917 at [56]–[58]; Beale v GIO (NSW) (1997) 48 NSWLR 430 (failure to provide reasons for rejecting corroborated evidence); Mifsud v Campbell (1990) 21 NSWLR 725; Chouman v Margules (1993) 17 MVR 144 (failure to advert to critical evidence overlooked during the course of the trial); Whalen v Kogarah Municipal Council [2007] NSWCA 5; BC200700445 (failure to give adequate reasons and failure to consider relevant evidence).
Examples of inadequate reasons: The following instances provide illustrative examples where reasons have been held to be inadequate—

reproducing the submissions of the parties without making explicit reasoned findings on critical matters: Commissioner for Railways (Qld) v Peters (1991) 24 NSWLR 407; 102 ALR 579 ; Pollard v Wilson [2010] NSWCA 68; BC201002744 at [165]–[166] ; LVR (WA) Pty Ltd v AAT (2012) 203 FCR 166; 128 ALD 489; [2012] FCAFC 90; BC201204504 ;

failing to state the basis for findings of liability or the assessment of damages: New South Wales Insurance Ministerial Corp v Mesiti (NSWCA, Mahoney, Handley and Sheller JJA, 1 December 1994, unreported, BC9403342);

making critical findings of fact merely on the basis of a declared preference for the evidence given by a particular witness: Wiki v Atlantis Relocations (NSW) Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 127; [2004] NSWCA 174; BC200403676 (preference given to an expert witness described as “more eminent”); Martin v Rowling [2005] QCA 128; BC200502477 (failure to explain selective preference for one of several conflicting medical experts); Sourlos v Luv a Coffee Lismore Pty Ltd [2007] NSWCA 203; BC200706503 (failure to give adequate reasons for accepting evidence of one expert over another); Young v Cesta-Incani [2007] NSWCA 229; BC200707521 (failure to give reasons for rejecting evidence of one expert as to accident circumstances); The Nominal Defendant v Kostic [2007] NSWCA 14; BC200700661 (failure to give adequate reasons for preferring particular medical evidence); K & M Prodanovski Pty Ltd v Calliden Insurance Ltd (2012) 60 MVR 456; [2012] NSWCA 117; BC201202850 (failure to choose between the competing opinions of expert witnesses by reference to the proved facts, the specialised knowledge of the witness and the reasoning process which produces the opinion tendered, and from there to give an explanation for preferring one opinion over the other: per Meagher JA at [25], Macfarlane JA, Tobias AJA agreeing);

making findings on the basis of demeanour without full regard to relevant evidence: Goodrich Aerospace Pty Ltd v Arsic (2006) 66 NSWLR 186; [2006] NSWCA 187; BC200605471 at [16]–[31] , [118] per Ipp JA;

failing to refer to critical evidence and documentary material, including material photographs or diagrams: Pollard v RRR Corp Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 110; BC200903917 at [63] (new trial ordered); Qushair v Raffoul [2009] NSWCA 329; BC200911105 at [82];

failing to state why a witness’s account in one area of the case has been accepted when the witness gave demonstrably false evidence in other areas, thereby impermissibly “quarantining” the witness’s proved lies and not using or transposing them as a means of assessing the other parts of his or her evidence neither corroborated nor shown to be false: Malco Engineering Pty Ltd v Ferreira (1994) 10 NSWCCR 117; BC9402316 per Handley JA at [117]; Divall v Mifsud [2005] NSWCA 447; BC200510783 at [42]; Brown v Harding [2008] NSWCA 51; BC200802107 ; Nominal Defendant v McLennan (2012) 61 MVR 1; [2012] NSWCA 148; BC201203253 ; see also [LCA07 s 7.15.10].
Legislation cited in [36.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 36.16, 36.17.

If a judgment has not been entered, the principles discussed in [36.16.45] , [36.16.50] and [36.16.53] may permit a court to recall reasons that have been affected by a material misapprehension, and to substitute a different order and provide different reasons: Elliott v R (2007) 234 CLR 38; 239 ALR 651; [2007] HCA 51; BC200709514 at [32] ; Fletcher Construction Australia Ltd v Lines MacFarlane & Marshall Pty Ltd (2001) 4 VR 28; [2001] VSCA 167; BC200106100 at [49] .

Apart from the situations contemplated by UCPR rr 36.16 and 36.17 (which deals with the “slip” rule) courts may revise reasons, especially reasons delivered ex tempore, to correct errors or infelicities of expression: Bar-Mordecai v Rotman [2000] NSWCA 123; BC200002479 at [193] ; Bromley v Bromley [1965] P 111; [1964] 3 All ER 226; [1964] 3 WLR 666 (permissible editing of court reporter’s shorthand notes to correct mistakes and unintended meaning). Permissible corrections include any errors, whether in the statement of facts or law, intended to ensure that the published reasons accurately and clearly express the judge’s intended meaning: Bell v Veigel [2008] NSWCA 36; BC200802104 at [220] ; (oversight in explicit reasoning — not involving material addition or alteration). They may also include corrections of grammar, style and format: Spencer v Bamber [2012] NSWCA 274; BC201206821 at [142]–[145] ; R v Jones (2010) 79 NSWLR 143; 242 FLR 64; [2010] NSWCCA 195; BC201006506 at [50]–[63] (reasons altered to insert words to clarify the originally intended meaning).

It is not permissible to make corrections that alter the substance of the published reasons: Todorovic v Moussa (2001) 53 NSWLR 463; [2001] NSWCA 419; BC200107217 at [46]–[48] (impermissible addition of a critical credit finding); Lam v Beesly (1992) 7 WAR 88 ; Loughnan v Altman (1992) 39 FCR 90; 111 ALR 445; 16 AAR 488; BC9203895 ; Bar-Mordecai v Rotman [2000] NSWCA 123; BC200002479 at [194] ; Schenck Australia Pty Ltd v Australian Coal Technology Pty Ltd [2006] NSWCA 211; BC200605763 at [29] (addition of reference to evidence without proper consideration in hearing): Burrell v R (2008) 238 CLR 218; 248 ALR 428; [2008] HCA 34; BC200806864 (impermissible to correct factual findings or assumptions, or include additional substantive reasons); Spencer v Bamber [2012] NSWCA 274; BC201206821 at [156]–[167] (revised reasons impermissible — contained additional factual findings and direction as to deemed service).

If a court’s published reasons have been impermissibly altered, the proper approach is to ignore the impermissible alterations: Palmer v Clarke [1989] 19 NSWLR 158 at 170; Spencer v Bamber [2012] NSWCA 274; BC201206821 at [139] and [169] .

As a general proposition, there is no requirement for a court to give reasons for the determination of merely procedural applications (Seymour v Sherian (NSWCA, 15 November 1983, unreported, BC8300496); Capital and Suburban Properties Ltd v Swycher [1976] Ch 319 at 325 ); in relation to rulings on the admissibility of evidence (Soulemezis v Dudley (Holdings) Pty Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 247 at 279 per McHugh JA; Bruton v New South Wales Ministerial Corp (NSWCA, Kirby P, Sheller and Cole JJA, No 40259/91, 6 December 1994, unreported, BC9403333)); or in relation to applications for leave to appeal; Southern Cross Exploration NL v Fire & All Risks Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) (1990) 21 NSWLR 200 at 215, 218 . However, these general propositions are subject to the circumstances of the particular case. For example, reasons may be required where the particular determination affects the substantive rights of the parties: Apps v Pilet (1987) 11 NSWLR 350 ; Southern Cross Exploration, above, at 214 per Kirby P; Decor Corp Pty Ltd v Dart Industries Inc (1991) 33 FCR 397; 104 ALR 621 at 623 . See also “Statements of Reasons for Judicial and Administrative Decisions” (1971) 33 Mod LR 154; Australian Breeders Co-op Society Ltd v Jones (1997) 150 ALR 488 at 503; 26 ACSR 26 ; Amadio Pty Ltd v Henderson (1998) 81 FCR 149 at 175 .

level.toc-caption: [36.2.25] Delay — adequacy of reasons where judgment given after substantial

heading.title: Delay — adequacy of reasons where judgment given after substantial

p.text: The adequacy of reasons invites particular scrutiny where there has been long delay in completing the hearing and the delivery of judgment. Long delay is inherently undesirable and tends to diminish confidence that the judge has fully attended to the complexity of the evidence and issues. It also reduces the judge's practical advantage in having seen and heard the witnesses give their evidence. All of these considerations combine to justify and probably require particular scrutiny of reasons for judgment that have been delivered long after the conclusion of the hearing.

Inadequacy of reasoning in a long delayed judgment, where the inadequacy relates to a failure to deal with specific evidence, or a failure to fully explain the rejection of evidence or the mere statement of a preference of one witness over another, may justify an order for a new trial: R v Maxwell (1998) 217 ALR 452; BC9807450 ; Bishopsgate Investment Management Ltd v Maxwell [1994] 1 All ER 261; [1993] BCC 120 (5 month delay after 5-day trial); Expectation Pty Ltd v PRD Realty Pty Ltd (2004) 140 FCR 17; 209 ALR 568; BC200404664 at [61]–[83] (21 month delay after 21 day trial); Hadid v Redpath (2001) 35 MVR 152; [2001] NSWCA 416; BC200107191 (judgment reserved for 12 months); Moylan v Nutrasweet Co (the Copper Seven case) [2000] NSWCA 337; BC200007222 (judgment reserved for 14 months); Mastronardi v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 54; BC200701760 at [60]–[71] (15 months between hearing and judgment — judgment dependent on plaintiff’s credibility — inaccurate summary of evidence and absence of explicit reasoning). Protracted delay may even provide a separate basis for challenging the decision under review if it constitutes a failure to provide a party with a real opportunity to have the evidence properly evaluated according to its merits: NAIS v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (2005) 223 ALR 171; [2005] HCA 77; BC200510689 at [77]–[107] (judicial review — credibility issues — 5 year delay — denial of procedural fairness); compare Monie v Commonwealth [2005] NSWCA 25; BC200501860 at [3] and [45] (18 month delay after 16 day trial — failure to deal with material evidence).

level.toc-caption: [36.2.30] Failure to give reasons and error of law

heading.title: Failure to give reasons and error of law

p.text: There are differing views as to whether a failure to give reasons constitutes an error of law. The dominant view appears to be that a failure to give adequate reasons will be regarded as an error of law: Dornan v Riordan (1990) 24 FCR 564 at 573; Re Poyser and Mills Arbitration [1964] 2 QB 467 at 477; [1963] 1 All ER 612; O’Brien v Repatriation Commission (1984) 1 FCR 472 at 504; 53 ALR 477; Pettitt v Dunkley [1971] 1 NSWLR 376 at 382, 385, 389; Apps v Pilet (1987) 11 NSWLR 350 ; Stoker v Adecco Gemvale Constructions Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 449; BC200408635 at [41] and following. On the other hand, there is another line of authority to the effect that a failure to give reasons does not, of itself, constitute an error of law: Law v Lee (1978) 19 SASR 442 ; Selvanayagam v University of the West Indies [1983] 1 WLR 585 at 587; Repatriation Commission v O’Brien (1985) 155 CLR 422 at 445–6; 58 ALR 119 per Brennan J; Brackenreg v Comcare Australia (1995) 56 FCR 335 at 343 ; Comcare Australia v Lees (1997) 151 ALR 647 at 656; BC9707019 ; contrast Soulemezis v Dudley (Holdings) Pty Ltd (1987) 10 NSWLR 247 at 281 per McHugh J. The difference between these two views appears to relate to the statutory context in which the question arises, and may have little practical relevance where there is a general right of appeal (ie one not restricted to matters of law): see Comcare Australia v Lees (1997) 151 ALR 647 at 656; BC9707019 . At least where there is a general right of appeal, the absence of sufficient reasons will not necessarily require setting aside the original decision: Stoker v Adecco Gemvale Constructions Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 449; BC200408635 at [41]–[43]; Zhang v Andrew Pine Furniture Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 250 at [31]; Beale v Government Insurance Office of New South Wales (1997) 48 NSWLR 430 at 444 . However, it is certainly the case that the absence of adequate reasons invites particular scrutiny of the judgment in order to determine whether it is affected by error: Repatriation Commission v O’Brien, above, at CLR 445–6 ; Bennett v Bennett (1991) FLC ¶92-191.

level.toc-caption: [36.2.35] Appeal — relevance of reasons to rights of

heading.title: Appeal — relevance of reasons to rights of

p.text: Whether or not the obligation to give reasons is confined to the extent necessary to give effect to a right of appeal (Kelly v Fay [1982] 1 NSWLR 232; contrast Housing Commission (NSW) v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378 at 386; (1983) 53 LGRA 325 ; Commission of New South Wales v Tatmar Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [1983] 3 NSWLR 378 at 386 ), if there is a right of appeal then a judge should give reasons that are sufficient to enable an appellate court to determine the precise findings of fact and law upon which the judgment is based. This is essential to the proper exercise of the right of appeal: Ex parte Merchant Banking Co of London; Re Durham (1881) 16 Ch D 623 at 635 ; Pettitt v Dunkley [1971] 1 NSWLR 376 ; Donges v Ratcliffe [1975] 1 NSWLR 501 ; Birch v Williams (1982) 6 Petty SR 2725 (NSWCA); Wright v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1977] 1 NSWLR 697 ; McCarroll v Fitzmaurice [1979] 2 NSWLR 100 ; Australian Timber Workers’ Union v Monaro Sawmills Pty Ltd (1980) 42 FLR 369 at 374; 29 ALR 322 ; R v Immigration Appeal Tribunal; Ex parte Khan [1983] QB 790 at 794 .

level.toc-caption: [36.2.40] Desirability of trial judges determining all issues

heading.title: Desirability of trial judges determining all issues

p.text: There is a long standing convention that trial judges who propose to find in favour of a defendant should, in a trial where damages have also been contested, proceed to assess damages — at least in those cases where there is a reasonably prospect of an appeal. A trial judge’s adherence to this convention assists in avoiding unnecessary expense, as well as the inconvenience in the taking up of valuable court time and resources, associated with any ultimate re-trial in the event of successful appeal on liability. The Court of Appeal has consistently encouraged trial judges to take this course: Wolfenden v International Theme Park Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 78; BC200803015 at [3]–[6] , [53] , [55] ; Nevin v B and R Enclosures [2004] NSWCA 339; BC200406279 ; Cook v R & M Reurich Holdings Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 268; BC200406259 (approving Lawrence v Nominal Defendant (1984) 1 MVR 388; BC8400320 ; Di Pietro v Hamilton (NSWCA, Kirby P, Clarke and Handley JJ, 6 September 1990, unreported, BC9002048).

This general convention applies most appropriately to the ordinary case, where the assessment of damages involves a relatively uncomplicated application of the liability findings to the particular damages claimed. It does not apply, at least not with the same force, where proper qualification of the recoverable damages depends on the precise nature of the liability issues in contest. There are cases where the contentious nature of the disputed liability issues makes any assessment of damages too hypothetical to undertake: Dansar Pty Ltd v Byron Shire Council [2013] NSWSC 17 (not just or convenient to make hypothetical determinations); Kelman v Mutton [2007] NSWSC 13; BC200700175 at [66] (“no sense” in trial judge quantifying the apportionment of liability between cross-claimant and cross-defendant after rejecting the premise of the cross-claim).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.3] r 36.3 Reserved decision (cf DCR Part 2A, rule 7, Part 31, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Reserved decision (cf DCR Part 2A, rule 7, Part 31, rule 10)

p.text: If in any proceedings a judicial officer reserves his or her judgment or decision on any question, he or she:
may give the judgment or decision, either in open court or in the absence of the public:
at the venue for those proceedings, or
at any other place at which he or she is authorised to hear or dispose of those proceedings, or
may reduce the judgment or decision to writing, sign it and forward it to the registrar at the venue for the proceedings.
If a registrar receives a judgment or decision forwarded under subrule (1)(b):
the registrar must appoint a time for the judgment or decision to be read, and
the registrar must give at least 24 hours’ notice to the parties, in writing or otherwise, of the appointed time, and
at the appointed time, the judgment or decision must be read by another judicial officer of the court, or by the registrar, whether or not the court is sitting at that time.

A judgment or decision given under subrule (1)(a) or read under subrule (2)(c) takes effect on the day on which it is so given or read and is as valid as if given by the judicial officer at the hearing of the proceedings to which the judgment or decision relates.
Rule 36.2 applies to a judgment or decision referred to in this rule in the same way as it applies to a judgment or decision referred to in that rule.
Legislation cited in [36.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.3.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA s 3.
(NSW) Judicial Officers Act 1986 s 3.

UCPR r 36.3 permits any judicial officer to deliver a reserved decision in the absence of the public. The practice of giving judgment in the absence of the public ought to be confined to disposal of undefended actions: Palmer v Clarke (1989) 19 NSWLR 158 per Kirby P; but it is not impermissible in other circumstances: McClymont v Owners-Strata Plan No 12139 [2009] NSWSC 276; BC200902727 at [69] per McCallum J (failure to give notice constituted a denial of natural justice but made no difference to the outcome). Although Assessors in the Local Court’s Small Claims Division do not fall within the definition of “judicial officer” in the relevant section of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 ( CPA s 3 ) and the Judicial Officers Act 1986 ( s 3 ), “this is merely due to legislative oversight (and) ... it is appropriate to assume that an Assessor is bound, and has authority, to proceed in accordance with the procedure under [UCPR] r 36.3”: McClymont , above, at [59].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.4] r 36.4 Date of effect of judgments and orders (cf SCR Part 40, rule 3; DCR Part 31, rule 13A(2))

leg:heading.title: Date of effect of judgments and orders (cf SCR Part 40, rule 3; DCR Part 31, rule 13A(2))

p.text: A judgment or order takes effect:
as of the date on which it is given or made, or
if the court orders that it not take effect until it is entered, as of the date on which it is entered.

Despite subrule (1), if an order of the court directs the payment of costs, and the costs are to be assessed, the order takes effect as of the date when the relevant cost assessor’s certificate is filed.
Despite subrules (1) and (2), the court may order that a judgment or order is to take effect as of a date earlier or later than the date fixed by those subrules.

level.toc-caption: [36.4.5] Date when the judgment takes effect

heading.title: Date when the judgment takes effect

p.text: Judgments and orders that have been pronounced in court generally take effect on the date they are made. If judgment is given otherwise than in court (for example, where default judgment is entered), it takes effect on the formal entry of judgment. The position under the rules is, therefore, similar to the position in England: Hunt v RM Douglas (Roofing) Ltd [1990] 1 AC 398; [1988] 3 All ER 823 ; Thomas v Bunn [1991] 1 AC 362; [1991] 1 All ER 193 ; Minister administering the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 v Carson (1994) 35 NSWLR 342 ; Parsons v Mather and Platt Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 715; [1977] 1 WLR 855 ; contrast RW Miller & Co Pty Ltd v The Ship Patris [1975] 1 NSWLR 704 at 723 (which was concerned with SCR Pt 40 r 3 before its amendment in 1990).

level.toc-caption: [36.4.7] Discretion to order judgment takes effect from earlier date

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.4.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 100, s 14, s 75A(6).
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 100.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.

heading.title: Discretion to order judgment takes effect from earlier date

p.text: Rule 36.4(3) allows the court to order that judgments and orders take effect earlier than the date they are formally made or entered and, in the case of costs orders, earlier than the date the costs assessor’s certificate is filed. The discretion conferred by the rule is primarily, though not exclusively, concerned with instances where there has been delay between the adjudication of the claims in the proceedings and the formal pronouncement of the judgment or order: Hartley Poynton Ltd v Ali [2005] VSCA 53; BC200501255 at [73] and [76]–[80].

The power is not confined to such instances, but the circumstances for its principled exercise in other situations is relatively circumscribed: Clyne v DCT (1984) 154 CLR 589; 55 ALR 143 at 597; BC8400473 (no power to backdate sequestration order); Belgian Grain and Produce Co Ltd v Cox & Co (France) Limited [1919] WN (Eng) 317 (exceptional circumstances required); Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Healy (No 2) (1991) 22 NSWLR 380 at 387; BC9102212 (in power exercisable to avoid and fairness); Tarrant v Statewide Secured Investments Ltd [2011] NSWCA 248; BC201106406 (orders not properly entered into the court’s computerised record system — direction to take effect when made); McKensey v Hewitt (2004) 61 NSWLR 54; [2004] NSWSC 636; BC200404573 at [37]–[53] (refusal of application to backdate an order for the payment of costs).

No question of ante-dating a judgment properly arises where a successful appeal results in the re-instatement of a judgment obtained at first instance: Nitrate SS Co v Short Bros (1922) 91 LJKB 871 ; Hartley Poynton Ltd v Ali , above at [30]. If the judgment reduces the amount of the first instance judgment it will impliedly operate from the date of the first instance judgment (Official Receiver in Bankruptcy v Schultz (1990) 170 CLR 306 at 318; 96 ALR 327; BC9002922 ) and may be expressly order to so operate: Kardos v Sarbutt (No 2) [2006] NSWCA 206; BC200605726 at [3]–[5], [55]–[57] . Where an appeal judgment awards damages refused at first instance the appeal powers (eg, CPA s 75A(6) and 100 and Supreme Court Act 1970 s 100 ) will permit a discretionary award of interest without the need to antedate the appeal judgment: Nicol v Allyacht Spars Pty Ltd (1988) 165 CLR 306; 81 ALR 272; BC8802664 . But a judgment may be antedated in order to provide for the payment of interest on the refund of part of a judgment debt that was overturned on appeal: Government Insurance Offıce (NSW) v Healy (No 2) (1991) 22 NSWLR 380 ; Nykredit Mortgage Bank plc v Edward Erdman Group Ltd [1997] 1 WLR 1627 . In addition, some procedural discretions are conferred in terms that necessarily contemplate orders being made with retrospective effect: see CPA s 14 and UCPR r 1.12 . Apart from these instances, and despite general statements to the contrary in some authorities, it will ordinarily be inappropriate to antedate a judgment, and especially if doing so would adversely affect the substantive rights of one of the parties: Hartley Poynton Ltd v Ali , above at [76]–[80].

level.toc-caption: [36.4.10] Order for payment of costs to be assessed

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 98(3).

heading.title: Order for payment of costs to be assessed

p.text: In the absence of a contrary order, orders for costs take effect when the costs assessor’s certificate is filed. However, unless a contrary order is made, interest will run from the date the costs were actually paid: see s 101(5)(a) of the CPA. If the costs have not been paid, interest will usually run from the date of the assesor’s certificate (or the effective date of any order which actually fixes the amount payable): Minister administering the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 v Carson (1994) 35 NSWLR 342 . As to the law before 1 January 1984, see TA Field Pty Ltd v Frigmobile of Australia Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 488 . The question whether costs orders are enforceable before the end of the proceedings is now determined by CPA s 98(3) , which expressly permits the court to make a costs order at any stage of the proceedings. The order may be enforced once it takes effect under the provisions of the present rule.

level.toc-caption: [36.4.12] Moneys held as security for costs

heading.title: Moneys held as security for costs

p.text: Moneys held as security for costs may be ordered to be paid out, at least subject to conditions requiring their proper application to costs, before any formal costs assessment. This course of action is permitted either because the money held as security is subject to the court’s general direction, or because the court can determine that a costs order takes effect before assessment: Summer Hill Business Estate Pty Ltd v Equititrust Ltd [2011] NSWCA 211; BC201105605 at [27]; Buzzle Operations Pty Ltd (in liq) v Apple Computer Australia Pty ltd (No 2) [2010] NSWSC 490; BC201003158 at [43]–[45].

level.toc-caption: [36.4.15] Order for payment of costs where the amount is fixed or agreed

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.4.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.4(1).

heading.title: Order for payment of costs where the amount is fixed or agreed

p.text: The rule does not deal with the situation where costs are ordered or agreed in a specific amount: Attorney-General (NSW) v Wentworth (1991) 24 NSWLR 347 . In such a case the judgment or order would take effect on the date when the order was made, or the date of entry, in accordance with UCPR r 36.4(1) . Interest would be payable from that date: Hunt v RM Douglas (Roofing) Ltd [1990] 1 AC 398; [1988] 3 All ER 823 ; TA Field Pty Ltd v Frigmobile of Australia Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 488 ; Fischer v David Syme & Co Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 606 ; Minister administering the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 v Carson (1994) 35 NSWLR 342 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.5] r 36.5 Time for compliance with judgments and orders (cf SCR Part 40, rule 4; DCR Part 31, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Time for compliance with judgments and orders (cf SCR Part 40, rule 4; DCR Part 31, rule 12)

p.text: If a judgment or order requires a person to do an act within a specified time, the court may, by order, require the person to do the act within another specified time.
If a judgment or order requires a person:
to do an act forthwith or forthwith on a specified event, or
to do an act but does not specify a time within which he or she is required to do the act,
the court may, by order, require the person to do the act within a specified time.
Legislation cited in [36.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.5(1).

Rule 36.5(2) makes clear the court’s power to specify a time even though the original order merely requires the act to be done “forthwith”. An order which requires a person to do an act “forthwith” is not an order fixing a specified time within the meaning of r 36.5(1) : Freeman v Trimble (1906) 6 SR (NSW) 133 . An omission to fix the time does not make the order ineffectual, but until it is fixed by a subsequent order, the order is unenforceable: Gilbert v Endean (1878) 9 Ch D 259 at 266 ; Carter v Roberts [1903] 2 Ch 312 .

An application to fixing a time may be refused where the obligation is conditional on the happening of some contingency, or interdependent with the performance of obligations by other parties: Qu v Kuang [2008] NSWSC 991; BC200808344 (an order for discharge of a mortgage and retransfer of property to a plaintiff was subject to a concurrent order on cross-claim for reimbursement of defendant's contributions).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.6] r 36.6 Judicial notice to be taken of orders and undertakings (cf SCR Part 40, rule 10; DCR Part 31, rule 14; LCR Part 26, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Judicial notice to be taken of orders and undertakings (cf SCR Part 40, rule 10; DCR Part 31, rule 14; LCR Part 26, rule 5)

p.text: In any proceedings, the court may take judicial notice of:
any order made by the court, or by any other court, and
any undertaking given to the court, or to any other court.
In any proceedings, the court may be informed of an order or undertaking by (among other things) reference to:
a note made by the judicial officer making the order or accepting the undertaking, or by his or her associate or by any other proper officer, or
a note made by the registrar or other officer making the order or accepting the undertaking.
The prescribed rate at which interest is payable under section 101 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 is:
in respect of the period from 1 January to 30 June in any year — the rate that is 6% above the cash rate last published by the Reserve Bank of Australia before that period commenced, and
in respect of the period from 1 July to 31 December in any year — the rate that is 6% above the cash rate last published by the Reserve Bank of Australia before that period commenced.
[r 36.7 subst Amendment 32 of 2010 Sch 1[5] effective 1 July 2010]
Different rates apply to the periods before and after judgment.

Pre-judgment interest CPA s 100: Originating proceedings must indicate whether pre-judgment interest is claimed and, in the case of a liquidated claim must specify the interest period and rates claimed. Ordinarily the court will award pre-judgment interest under CPA s 100 in accordance with the published Reserve Bank of Australia cash rate as at 1 January and 1 July during the claim period, plus a prescribed margin: see UCPR r 6.12.8, Practice Note SC Gen 16 and DC (Civil) 15. The margin is less than that which applies to post judgement interest:
See also:
Supreme Court Practice Note SC Gen 16 — Pre-judgment Interest rates
District Court Practice Note DC (Civil) No 15 — Pre-judgment Interest rates
Local Court Practice Note Civ 1 — Cl 22 Pre-judgment Interest rates
Land and Environment Court — Practice Note Pre-judgment Interest Rates (22 June 2010)
Industrial Relations Commission — Practice Note No 25 Prejudgment Interest Rates.
The ordinary interest rates are set out in the table below.

Interest on judgments CPA s 101: Judgments unpaid after more than 28 days ordinarily bear interest. Orders for the payment of costs may also include an order for the payment of interest: see CPA s 101. Judgment interest of this kind is payable at the rate prescribed in the present rule. Those rates, and their comparison to the ordinary rates for pre-judgment interest, are set out in the table below.

Pre 1 July 2010: Interest calculations to 30 June 2010 are calculated by reference to those rates prescribed at UCPR Sch 5 (now repealed). See table at [36.7.15] below. The regulation amending UCPR 36.7 had no transitional provisions. There is no indication that the amendment is intended to operate retrospectively. It should not operate retrospectively: Woolworths Ltd v Strong (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 72; BC201102952 at [56]–[65] (the applicable interest rate should be ascertained, up to 1 July 2010, by reference to Sch 5 as it was from time to time up to 1 July 2010. The new provision in UCPR 36.7 should only apply from 1 July 2010).

Post July 2010: Where an order made before 1 July 2010 specifies that interest is payable at rates in Sch 5 of the UCPR, it is not necessary to amend the order to reflect that the prescribed rate of interest payable under s 101 CPA is now identified in UCPR 36.7: Kation Pty Ltd v Lamru Pty Ltd (No 5) [2010] NSWCA 294; BC201009840 ; Lahoud v Lahoud [2011] NSWSC 994; BC201106786 at [14] (words requiring interest to be paid “at rates set out in Sch 5 UCPR” should be construed, for the period after 1 July 2010, as requiring interest to be paid in accordance with the current version of UCPR 36.7).
Note: For Reserve Bank Cash Rate see www.rba.gov.au/statistics/cash-rate/index.html .
See also:
Supreme Court Practice Note SC Gen 16 — Pre-judgment Interest rates
District Court Practice Note DC (Civil) No 15 — Pre-judgment Interest rates
Local Court Practice Note Civ 1 — Cl 22 Pre-judgment Interest rates
Land & Environment Court — Practice Note Pre-judgment Interest Rates (22 June 2010)
Industrial Relations Commission — Practice Note No 25 Pre-judgment Interest Rates.

Before 1 July 2010 the applicable judgment interest rates were prescribed in UCPR Sch 5. The changed interest rates required by UCPR Amendment No 32 apply to both new and existing proceedings. They apply also prospectively to any then existing unpaid judgment: Simonius Vischer & Co v Holt & Thompson [1979] 2 NSWLR 322 ; Kelly v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1987) 9 NSWLR 369 . But the previously prescribed rates can be expected to apply to claim and judgment periods before 1 July 2010: Woolworths Ltd v Strong (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 72; BC201102952 at [56]–[65] (rates do not apply retrospectively). Those rates, for the period from March 2000 to July 2010, are set out in the following table.

entry.emph: (UCPR Sch 5 — repealed by UCPR Amendment No 32)

p.text: Legislation cited in [36.7.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18(4).
(NSW) Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73.

Various statutory provisions restrict the rate of interest to be used in particular types of proceedings: Civil Liability Act 2002 s 18(4) (10 year benchmark bond rate); Motor Accidents Act 1988 s 73 (¾ of the rate prescribed for the purposes of CPA s 101 for the period concerned); Workers Compensation Act s 151M (¾ of the rate prescribed for the purposes of CPA s 101 for the period concerned): see [s 100.80].
The relevant table for s 18(4) of the Civil Liability Act 2002 is set out below.
The relevant interest rate is represented by Commonwealth Government 10-year benchmark bond rate as published by the Reserve Bank of Australia as applies:
on the first business day of January each year (for the period from 1 Mar until 31 Aug of that year); or
on the first business day of July each year (for the period 1 Sept until the last day of Feb of the following year).
For 10-year benchmark bond rate see www.rba.gov.au/statistics/tables/index.html#content (Capital Market yields — Government bonds — daily).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.8] r 36.8 Possession of land (cf SCR Part 40, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Possession of land (cf SCR Part 40, rule 11)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, judgment for possession of land may not be given or entered against a defendant in his or her absence unless the plaintiff files an affidavit:
stating that, when the originating process was filed or (if the claim for possession arises from an amendment to the originating process) when the amendment was made:
specified persons (other than parties to the proceedings) had been in occupation of the whole or any part of the land, or
no persons (other than parties to the proceedings) had been in occupation of the whole or any part of the land, and
stating that, as to each person specified in accordance with paragraph (a)(i) (other than a person whose occupation the plaintiff does not seek to disturb):
the originating process has been duly served on the person, or
the person has, since the time referred to in paragraph (a), ceased to be in occupation of any part of the land, and
in relation to a claim for possession by reason of default in the payment of money, stating particulars of the default.
See Form 36 for the approved form of Notice of Motion — default judgment on claim for possession of land.
An arrest warrant issued by order of the court must be signed by a judicial officer or by a registrar.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 36.10] r 36.10 Filing of cost assessors’ certificates (cf SCR Part 40, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Filing of cost assessors’ certificates (cf SCR Part 40, rule 12)

p.text: A cost assessor’s certificate:
may be filed in the proceedings to which it relates, or
may be filed in fresh proceedings, whether in the same court or another court.
A number of certificates may be filed together under subrule (1) if each of the certificates:
relates to the same costs assessment, and
requires the same person or persons to pay costs.
[subs (2) subst Amendment 39 of 2010 Sch 1, effective 10 December 2010]

If some of the costs specified in the certificate or certificates have been paid, the certificate or certificates must be accompanied by an affidavit, sworn not earlier than 14 days before the certificate or certificates are filed, stating the amount of the costs that have been paid.
[subs (3) insrt Amendment 39 of 2010 Sch 1, effective 10 December 2010]
The certificate or certificates will, from the date of filing, be taken to be a judgment of the court under Division 11 of Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 for:
if the certificate or certificates are not accompanied by an affidavit under subrule (3) — the total amount of costs specified in the certificate or certificates, or
if the certificate or certificates are accompanied by an affidavit under subrule (3) — the amount of costs that have not been paid.
[Note insrt Amendment 39 of 2010 Sch 1, effective 10 December 2010]
In the Supreme Court costs assessment certificates should be filed using Form 45 (reproduced at [451,940]), together with the required affidavit and the appropriate fee.
Legislation cited in [36.10.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 Div 11, s 368.

Costs Assessment is carried out under Pt 3.2 Div 11 of the Legal Profession Act 2004 (LPA 2004). Filed costs assessment certificates operate as a judgment of the court for the amount of any unpaid costs assessed: see s 368 of the Legal Profession Act 2004.

A costs assessor’s certification of determination can be filed either in the proceedings to which the costs relate or in fresh proceedings. If there are no current proceedings the filing of the certificate is taken involve fresh proceedings: Coshott v Barry [2012] NSWSC 850; BC201206340 at [47] .

Filed costs assessment certificates are “taken to be a judgment” of the court for the amount of unpaid costs: see s 368 of the Legal Profession Act 2004. This enlivens the usual procedures for the enforcement of a judgment for the payment of money, but it does not make the certificate a judgment of the court: Frumar v Owners of Strata Plan 36957 [2010] NSWCA 172; BC201006901 at [42] . The review procedures set out in the Legal Profession Act (not the ordinary procedures for appeal) apply to the certificate of determination. If the certificate is liable to be set aside, the “judgment” may also be set aside (without any appeal from the judgment: Doyle v Hall Chadwick [2007] NSWCA 159; BC200705261 at [47]–[54] . Further information about costs assessments is available on the NSW Supreme Court website at: http://www.supremecourt.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/ supremecourt/sco2_costsassessment.html .

Assessment does not involve court proceedings and is not subject to the UCPR. Nevertheless, if the costs assessment is subsequently altered on appeal, the court may set aside the judgment created by the prior filing of the assessment certificate, and order the repayment of any monies paid under that judgment: Frumar v Owners of Strata Plan 36957 [2010] NSWCA 172; BC201006901 at [42] , [44] ; Doyle v Hall Chadwick [2007] NSWCA 159; BC200705261 at [47]–[54] . Conversely, the mere expiry of a limitation period for any cause of action in relation to the underlying cost liability does not provide a basis for setting aside such a judgment: Coshott v Barry (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 944; BC201206968 at [18] .

level.toc-caption: [36.10.10] Affidavit where costs have been partly paid

heading.title: Affidavit where costs have been partly paid

p.text: If the assessed costs have not been paid, any filed certificates operate as judgments of the court from the date of filing: see Legal Profession Act 2004 s 368(5). If the costs have been partly paid, only the balance is recoverable as a judgment of the court. In the latter case UCPR r 36.10(3) requires the party seeking a costs order to file an affidavit of part payment, but relieves them from any obligation to obtaining a specific direction for the entry of judgment. There is no requirement to file an affidavit if none of the assessed costs have been paid: Falamaki v Wollongong City Council [2009] NSWSC 871; BC200907829 , per McClellan CJ at CL at [8], [11] (dealing with the pre 2010 version of UCPR rr 36.10(2) & (3)).
